posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version of the text, adhering to the requirements:

---

The text is:  
Inspired by this post:  

FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears?  

These could be about the program, misconceptions, things that people say incorrectly, or anything else you all think applies.  

I’ll go ahead first. I don’t like when people refer to the sparkMAX motor control as a spark. That’s a whole different product, aimed at a completely different set of motors!  

Now your turn, w…  

What are your programming pet peeves? This could be about how your teammates write code, or something in WPILib or external vendor libraries/api’s that you might not like, or anything else.  

---

link_counts.title: FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears?

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked: people that don’t read the documentation before asking questions (99% of the time, your issues will be solved by reading the documentation)

link_counts.title: FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears?

posts.name: Drew Williams
posts.cooked: Java

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: Gradle's build times are particularly fast, especially on students' laptops. Additionally, Gradle can build C++ projects efficiently.
Hungarian notation, especially since all the WPILib examples use it, might end up in lots of teams’ code where no one truly understands why it’s there.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: Hungarian notation is used to denote variable attributes based on their memory model in C++. In this case, 'm_' indicates a modifiable pointer, suggesting it can be changed during runtime. '_k' likely denotes a kept-alive pointer, requiring explicit memory management. These notations help manage object lifetimes effectively, though overuse may cause confusion. Proper documentation is key to clear communication among developers.

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked:
EXTRAordinarily IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH.  
The text is:  
"When people post to these forums asking for help with their code and all you have to work with is a screenshot of their code. If I want to help them and correct their code, I need to type it all out again. Some important bits will probably be cut off."  
"This situation typically occurs with users who have limited coding experience. However, there are two effective methods to share code:**  
1. Use markdown formatting with code blocks enclosed by triple backticks. You can specify the programming language after the first set of backticks.  
2. Share a link to the file you're working on in your branch of a GitHub repository."

link_counts.title: FRC pet peeves: what really grinds your gears?

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: When attempting to open the command palette, the WPILIB Simulate Robot Code initiates, prompting you to wait for a rebuild or check. Chat messages suggest using Sim GUI or Real DriverStation instead, after which the simulation begins. However, each time you run this, you become distracted within a short timeframe (minutes on some laptops), causing you to restart frequently. Ideally, the program would request confirmation before continuing.
The change in WPILib this year required Spark Maxes to require an additional object, SparkMaxConfig, to invert motors instead of using deprecated methods. Edit: Realized that it was due to RevLib.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: Programmers https://www.chiefdelphi.com/images/emoji/google/slight_smile.png?v=12

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: I think you have a bone to pick with Rev Robotics, not WPILib. Revlib is the library used to control Spark Maxes, which is separate from WPILib.
Feedback and feedforward constants without units, especially when they are not in base SI units or radians.

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked: Do you often find yourself choosing each of them? A little known option is to bypass this check by changing "Skip Select Simulate Extension" in the VSCode options for WPILib. For example, I almost never use DS<abbreviation>sim</abbreviation> so just have it always auto go to the simGUI but some people have it auto skip simGUI instead.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: My hero. <3 Works like a charm. I'm on Linux, so I can't run the real Driverstation anyway.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: i really liked the part where rev refactored the entire library and changed a bunch of units and whatnot breaking pretty much everything (at least for us)

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked: I'm on Linux, so I can't run the real Driverstation anyway. That's another pet peeve. Why is there so much Windows-only FRC stuff and a lot of non-open-source as well?

Another recently discovered pet peeve I have is that when working with C++, I find it confusing that one command is split across two files—a Command.h header file and a separate Command.cpp source file. This setup is unfamiliar compared to my experience with Java, where typically one file suffices per command or subsystem.

posts.name: Stephen Ostermiller
posts.cooked: It can still be your pet peeve, but there are technical reasons based on how C++ is defined and implemented.

link_counts.title: c++ - Why have header files and .cpp files? - Stack Overflow

posts.cooked: Chunky if-else blocks are often preferred over switch statements when dealing with sequential control flow.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Setting the invert wrong on two motors on the same gearbox really grinds my gears! Not my gears, our gears really.
